questions.text: The following documents are exceptions to oral evidence in court:

options.label: B
options.text: Dying declaration if the victim survived

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reports of Fingerprint Bureau

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that certain technical and scientific documents, such as Reports of the Fingerprint Bureau , are exceptions to oral evidence in court. These reports are straightforward and don't require further oral explanation, making them admissible as documentary evidence.
  • ➤ Reports of the Fingerprint Bureau

questions.text: During a late-night shift in a district hospital's emergency department, a medical officer is urgently called to attend to a patient with critical injuries from a hit-and-run accident. As the patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, the medical officer realizes the importance of recording the patient's account of the incident, suspecting it might be the patient's dying declaration. Given the urgency of the situation and the legal significance of the patient's statement, which of the following actions aligns best with the protocol for recording a dying declaration in India?

options.label: A
options.text: The medical officer must wait for the presence of the accused and their lawyer before recording the patient's statement.

options.label: B
options.text: The medical officer can record the patient's statement only if the magistrate is present.

options.label: C
options.text: The medical officer is allowed to ask leading questions to quickly gather all necessary information from the patient.

options.label: D
options.text: If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value

questions.correct_answer: D. If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) If the patient unexpectedly recovers, the recorded statement will lose its value

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that a dying declaration can be recorded by any responsible individual, not necessarily a magistrate. If the patient survives, the statement loses its full legal value and becomes corroborative evidence. Leading questions are not allowed, and the presence of the accused or their lawyer is not required during the recording.
  • ➤ dying declaration

questions.text: 32-year-old women married for 5 years was found deceased under suspicious circumstances in a rented apartment in Mumbai. The case has drawn significant media attention, and there is pressure on authorities to conduct a thorough investigation. According to the Indian legal process, which type of inquest will be done?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that in India, a magistrate inquest is conducted in cases of dowry deaths and custodial deaths . For deaths of women occurring within seven years of marriage under suspicious circumstances, a magistrate inquest is mandatory as per Indian law.
  • ➤ magistrate inquest
  • ➤ dowry deaths
  • ➤ custodial deaths

questions.text: Dr. Aarav, serving as an expert witness in a pivotal medical malpractice lawsuit, has concluded his initial testimony. As the proceedings transition to the cross-examination phase, the defense counsel gears up for an exhaustive session of questioning. In the context of legal procedure, what is the customary time allocation for the cross-examination phase in a trial?

options.label: A
options.text: Total working hours on the day of evidence

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) No time limit

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that in the Indian legal system, cross-examination does not have a fixed time limit. The defense counsel is allowed to continue questioning the witness for as long as necessary to clarify or challenge the testimony.
  • ➤ cross-examination

questions.text: Dr. Anand, a distinguished orthopedic surgeon, has been invited to give expert testimony in a complicated case where a fellow surgeon is accused of negligence during a hip arthroplasty. In the course of preparing for his deposition, Dr. Anand revisits legal terminologies pertinent to his testimony, particularly concerning witness compensation known as 'conduct money'. Which of the following assertions about 'conduct money' is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is paid by the defendant.

options.label: B
options.text: It is paid after the witness is done in the court.

options.label: C
options.text: The amount is decided by the plaintiff.

options.label: D
options.text: It is paid by the Plaintiff.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is paid by the Plaintiff.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is paid by the Plaintiff.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that in civil cases, conduct money is paid by the plaintiff to ensure that witnesses are compensated for their time and travel before appearing in court.
  • ➤ conduct money
  • ➤ plaintiff

questions.text: Dr. Singh, a cardiologist in New Delhi, is under investigation after several complaints from patients regarding his prescription practices, which allegedly violate the nationally recognized medical code of ethics. He is accused of overprescribing medications in exchange for incentives from a pharmaceutical company. In the context of medical regulation in India, to which authority can Dr. singh appeal if he is punished by state medical council?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Central Health Ministry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that in cases of punishment for professional misconduct by the State Medical Council , the appeal can be made to the Central Health Ministry , which may consult the National Medical Commission .
  • ➤ professional misconduct
  • ➤ State Medical Council
  • ➤ Central Health Ministry
  • ➤ National Medical Commission

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy Gautam is accused of causing a grievous hurt to an elderly man in his neighborhood. The case of Gautam will be tried in a juvenile court which has a Juvenile justice board. Which of the following is true with respect to composition of juvenile justice board?

options.label: A
options.text: Three Social workers of which two must be women

options.label: C
options.text: Judicial Magistrate of first class who must be a woman

questions.correct_answer: B. Judicial Magistrate of first class
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Judicial Magistrate of first class

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that the Juvenile Justice Board is composed of one judicial magistrate of the first class and two social workers , one of whom must be a woman. This ensures both legal authority and social expertise in handling juvenile cases.
  • ➤ Juvenile Justice Board
  • ➤ one judicial magistrate of the first class
  • ➤ two social workers

questions.text: In a lecture on the professional conduct of healthcare workers, a forensic expert is explaining the concepts of medical etiquette and medical ethics to medical students. The expert emphasizes the differences between these two concepts and asks the students to identify the correct description of medical etiquette. What does medical ethics specifically refer to?

options.label: B
options.text: Customs of courtesy among members of the same profession

options.label: C
options.text: Moral principles in dealings with patients and the state

options.label: D
options.text: Having reasonable skill in treating patients

questions.correct_answer: C. Moral principles in dealings with patients and the state
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Moral principles in dealings with patients and the state

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students must understand that medical ethics refer to the set of moral principles that guide healthcare professionals in their interactions with patients, colleagues, and society. This includes ensuring patient well-being, autonomy, and justice in medical decision-making.

questions.text: A patient is brought into the emergency room after a severe car accident. The patient is unconscious and in critical condition, with multiple injuries. In this situation, the healthcare team may need to perform various surgical procedures, such as: Emergency surgery to stop internal bleeding. Orthopedic surgery to repair broken bones. Neurosurgery to relieve pressure on the brain. Plastic surgery to address facial injuries. Thoracic surgery to treat lung injuries. The healthcare team explains all the risks and different types of surgeries that will be required for multiple injuries. This is a type of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Informed consent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that informed consent involves providing comprehensive information about medical procedures, risks, and alternatives. Even in emergencies, when a legal representative is available, informed consent must be obtained through clear communication of the necessary treatments and associated risks.
  • ➤ informed consent

questions.text: The post-mortem examination of a body shows transverse intimal tears on the carotid artery as below. What could be the most probable cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse intimal tears of the carotid artery are characteristic of hanging, where the force applied to the neck by the noose can cause this type of internal vascular injury. While other forms of neck compression (like strangulation) can cause vascular damage, this specific type of tear is more commonly seen in cases of hanging.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes is scheduled for an elective hernia repair. Upon admission, he is presented with a document to sign, which consents to the surgery and any additional necessary procedures that may be discovered intraoperatively. This type of consent implies that the patient agrees to all aspects of care, including those not specifically mentioned in the document, provided they are in the course of standard treatment. How is this form of consent best described?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blanket consent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that blanket consent is a general consent given by a patient to cover all aspects of treatment, including those not explicitly mentioned in the document. This type of consent is often used in cases where additional procedures may become necessary during treatment.
  • ➤ blanket consent

questions.text: A 24-year-old man was found deceased in his living room, suspended by a rope from the ceiling fan. The knot was tied to the right side of his neck. During the examination, the forensic expert observed a distinctive pattern of salivary staining. Based on the positioning of the knot and the principles of forensic medicine, where would the dribbling of saliva most likely be found in this case of atypical hanging?

options.label: A
options.text: Towards the site of the knot

options.label: B
options.text: Opposite the site of the knot

options.label: C
options.text: At both angles of the mouth

questions.correct_answer: B. Opposite the site of the knot
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Opposite the site of the knot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of atypical hanging , the dribbling of saliva is usually found on the side opposite to the knot, as the rope's compression and the force of gravity affect the flow of saliva from the mouth. This is a key forensic detail in confirming the mechanics of the hanging.
  • ➤ atypical hanging
  • ➤ dribbling of saliva
  • ➤ opposite

questions.text: A dead body is brought for autopsy. On examination of neck, a ligature that was present obliquely, and above the level of the thyroid was seen. Subcutaneous tissue under the mark was white and glistening. What is the cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of hanging , the ligature mark is typically oblique, incomplete, and above the level of the thyroid . The subcutaneous tissue under the mark often appears white and glistening due to the compression of the ligature, distinguishing it from other forms of neck compression such as strangulation or throttling.
  • ➤ hanging
  • ➤ oblique, incomplete, and above the level of the thyroid
  • ➤ white and glistening

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should memorize the age range for the eruption of permanent teeth , which is crucial for understanding normal dental development and identifying any anomalies.
  • ➤ permanent teeth

questions.text: Number of temporary teeth at 5 years:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that a 5-year-old typically has 20 primary (temporary) teeth . The primary teeth start erupting at around 6 months and are all present by 2 years . They begin to fall out around 6 years , when the permanent teeth start to come in.
  • ➤ 5-year-old
  • ➤ 20 primary (temporary) teeth
  • ➤ 6 months
  • ➤ 2 years
  • ➤ 6 years

questions.text: A young camper was found unresponsive in the shallow waters near the shore early in the morning. Initial suspicions pointed towards an accidental drowning, but the expert's keen observations suggest there might be more to the story. Forensic expert explains the critical nuances of freshwater drowning to the investigative team, focusing on the physiological effects that could lead to fatal outcomes. What is the most likely cause of ventricular fibrillation in this case of freshwater drowning?

options.label: A
options.text: Total asphyxia induced by the panic and struggle in water

options.label: B
options.text: Cold water shock leading to involuntary laryngeal spasm

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid fluid shifts causing blood thickening and clot formation

options.label: D
options.text: Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

questions.correct_answer: D. Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hemodilution from absorbed freshwater, leading to an electrolyte imbalance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In freshwater drowning , hemodilution leads to hyperkalemia , which can cause ventricular fibrillation and death. This is distinct from saltwater drowning, where different electrolyte shifts occur, leading to other fatal outcomes.
  • ➤ freshwater drowning
  • ➤ hemodilution
  • ➤ hyperkalemia
  • ➤ ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. Among the listed factors, which one indicate drowning prior to death:

options.label: C
options.text: Large amount of fine, white leathery foam around mouth, nostrils and in airway

questions.correct_answer: C. Large amount of fine, white leathery foam around mouth, nostrils and in airway
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Large amount of fine, white leathery foam around mouth, nostrils and in airway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of antemortem drowning , the presence of froth in the airways, nostrils, and mouth is one of the strongest indicators of drowning before death. While other signs such as washerwoman's hands and water in the stomach can also be present, froth remains the most reliable and visible sign.
  • ➤ antemortem drowning
  • ➤ froth
  • ➤ strongest indicators

questions.text: Which of the following feature is related to the mandible of female?
questions.correct_answer: A. Angle of ramus - More obtuse
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Angle of ramus - More obtuse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that the angle of the ramus in the mandible of females is more obtuse compared to males, whose mandibles have sharper angles and more prominent features such as larger condyles and mental tubercles.
  • ➤ angle of the ramus
  • ➤ more obtuse

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late?

options.label: A
options.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

options.label: B
options.text: Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax

options.label: C
options.text: Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax

options.label: D
options.text: Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.correct_answer: B. Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand the progression of rigor mortis, which follows a head-to-toe pattern. The sequence typically begins with the small muscles of the eyelids , followed by the neck and facial muscles , then progresses downward to the upper limbs , thorax , abdomen , and finally the lower limbs .
  • ➤ eyelids
  • ➤ neck
  • ➤ facial muscles
  • ➤ upper limbs
  • ➤ thorax
  • ➤ abdomen
  • ➤ lower limbs

questions.text: A skull was recovered from a forest. According to inquest papers, woman had gone missing after a fight with her boyfriend a month back. The skull was sent to the forensic research lab. Which of the following would identify it as a female skull? Prominent external occipital protuberance Heavy cheek bones Square orbits Large mastoid
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that male skulls are typically larger, heavier, and have more pronounced features compared to female skulls , which are generally smoother and less prominent. The listed features in this question are typical of male skulls, not female skulls.
  • ➤ male skulls
  • ➤ female skulls

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about fresh water drowning:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypovolemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In freshwater drowning , the primary changes include hypervolemia , hemolysis , hyperkalemia , and the risk of ventricular fibrillation . Hypovolemia is not a characteristic of freshwater drowning and is therefore the incorrect statement in this context.
  • ➤ freshwater drowning
  • ➤ hypervolemia
  • ➤ hemolysis
  • ➤ hyperkalemia
  • ➤ ventricular fibrillation
  • ➤ Hypovolemia

questions.text: Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 21 cm. Both testes are seen near the external inguinal ring. The gestational age of the fetus will be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 7 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Crown Rump Length (CRL) of 21 cm corresponds to approximately 7 months of gestation, and the presence of the testes near the external inguinal ring further supports this estimate.
  • ➤ Crown Rump Length (CRL) of 21 cm
  • ➤ 7 months

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is examining a set of skeletal remains discovered at an archaeological site. The mandible is relatively well preserved. The focus is on determining the sex of the individual based on the mandible. Which of the following features will be found in male mandible as compared to female mandible?

options.label: A
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: B
options.text: Round Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: C
options.text: Square Chin, more obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: D
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, smaller body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

questions.correct_answer: A. Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that male mandibles tend to have a square chin , a less obtuse angle , greater body height at the symphysis , and a broader ascending ramus compared to female mandibles.
  • ➤ male mandibles
  • ➤ square chin
  • ➤ less obtuse angle
  • ➤ greater body height at the symphysis
  • ➤ broader ascending ramus

questions.text: Dead Body of fetus was found submerged in water by a local fisherman. The crown heel length was found to be 25 cm, and length of lower limbs was 10 cm. Few hairs were present on his body and ossification center of calcaneum was present. Approximate age of the fetus is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a Crown Heel Length (CHL) of 25 cm , the approximate gestational age is 5 months , as calculated using the formula length divided by 5 . Additional signs like the presence of hair and the ossification center in the calcaneum further confirm this estimate.
  • ➤ Crown Heel Length (CHL) of 25 cm
  • ➤ 5 months
  • ➤ length divided by 5

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found unresponsive in his apartment with multiple bloodstains on his clothing. The first responders to the scene need to determine whether the bloodstains are recent or if some might have been present for a longer period. Which method should the forensic team use to confirm the presence of blood in both the recent and older stains on the clothing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Spectroscopic test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should remember that spectroscopic testing is both sensitive and specific for detecting blood in both recent and old stains. While presumptive tests are useful for initial detection, spectroscopy provides the most reliable confirmation of the presence of blood, regardless of the stain’s age.
  • ➤ spectroscopic testing

questions.text: False negative hydrostatic test in live born fetus is for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atelectasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A false negative hydrostatic test can occur in cases of atelectasis , where the lungs fail to inflate properly despite the infant having taken breaths. Artificial respiration and putrefaction , on the other hand, cause false positive results in the hydrostatic test.
  • ➤ false negative hydrostatic test
  • ➤ atelectasis
  • ➤ Artificial respiration
  • ➤ putrefaction
  • ➤ false positive

questions.text: A girl runs away from home with her boyfriend and they get married. In court, she says that she is a major. Identify the age of the girl from the Xray of her pelvis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) > 21 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that skeletal maturity is determined by the fusion of certain bones, particularly the pelvis and femur, with full fusion indicating an age of over 21 years .
  • ➤ skeletal maturity
  • ➤ 21 years

questions.text: A dead born foetus does not have:

options.label: C
options.text: Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months

questions.correct_answer: C. Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rigor mortis if gestational age is < 7 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A dead-born fetus will not develop rigor mortis if its gestational age is less than 7 months due to the lack of muscular and metabolic development needed for rigor mortis to occur.
  • ➤ dead-born fetus
  • ➤ rigor mortis
  • ➤ less than 7 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to prescribed antipsychotic medication. The prosecution has charged the individual with the offense. Based on the provided information, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the criminal responsibility of mentally ill?

options.label: A
options.text: The accused will be responsible since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication.

options.label: B
options.text: The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

options.label: C
options.text: The accused will be responsible due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms.

options.label: D
options.text: The accused will not be responsible only if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness.

questions.correct_answer: B. The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The accused will not be responsible as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that under legal provisions like Section 84 IPC or 22 BNS , individuals who commit offenses during acute psychotic episodes may not be held criminally responsible, as their mental state prevents them from comprehending the nature of their actions. Medication adherence is not a determining factor in criminal responsibility.
  • ➤ Section 84 IPC
  • ➤ 22 BNS

questions.text: A baby is still born in the hospital, but still has signs of respiration. Which is true in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: This might be a case of vagitus vaginalis

options.label: B
options.text: This might be a case of vagitus uterinus

options.label: C
options.text: Can occur due to forceps delivery

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both A and B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vagitus vaginalis and vagitus uterinus are rare conditions where a baby may cry or take a breath while still in the vagina or uterus, which can result in respiratory signs even if the baby is stillborn. The baby must be alive after complete delivery to be considered a live birth, even if signs of respiration occurred prior to birth.
  • ➤ Vagitus vaginalis
  • ➤ vagitus uterinus

questions.text: A person is accused of committing Rape. He claims to be adolescent. He is brought to the government hospital for age estimation to determine if he should be sent to juvenile home or an adult jail. The X-ray image of the pelvis is shown below. What is the age?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 17-18 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pelvic bone fusion, especially of the iliac crest and ischial tuberosity, is used in forensic age estimation. Full fusion in these bones occurs around 17-18 years, helping determine the individual's age in cases of legal responsibility.

questions.text: A naked man is caught in his room who has installed hidden camera in a neighbour’s room who is a 18 year old girl, and peeping into her bathroom and trying to watch the female inhabitant’s bathe. This sexual perversion is defined as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Voyeurism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students must remember that voyeurism is the act of spying on individuals, typically in private settings, to gain sexual satisfaction, and it is distinct from other forms of sexual perversion like frotteurism, masochism, and exhibitionism.
  • ➤ voyeurism

questions.text: Dr. Nair, a medical officer, presents a challenging case to her peers for discussion. Dr. Nair is particularly interested in discussing a phenomenon, where the deceased's body temperature remains abnormally high after death. She asks her colleagues to identify which condition among the listed is least likely to be associated with this unusual postmortem finding.

options.label: A
options.text: Exposure to extreme heat leading to sunstroke

options.label: B
options.text: Fatal convulsions resulting from strychnine poisoning

options.label: C
options.text: Overwhelming systemic infection known as septicemia

options.label: D
options.text: Overdose of a central nervous system depressant, such as barbiturates

questions.correct_answer: D. Overdose of a central nervous system depressant, such as barbiturates
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Overdose of a central nervous system depressant, such as barbiturates

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conditions such as sunstroke , strychnine poisoning , and septicemia can cause postmortem caloricity , where the body temperature remains high after death due to pre-death disturbances in heat regulation. In contrast, an overdose of CNS depressants like barbiturates leads to hypothermia , making it the least likely to cause postmortem caloricity.
  • ➤ sunstroke
  • ➤ strychnine poisoning
  • ➤ septicemia
  • ➤ postmortem caloricity
  • ➤ CNS depressants
  • ➤ hypothermia
  • ➤ least likely

questions.text: What type of smell is produced by the decomposed body from the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Odorless

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mummification is a process in which the body becomes desiccated, leading to a thin, brown appearance. Due to the lack of moisture, mummified bodies are odorless because the bacteria responsible for producing foul smells in putrefaction cannot thrive.
  • ➤ odorless

questions.text: Police officers found a completely burnt dead body of a person in a forest. They suspect that someone might have killed him and later burnt the dead body to avoid identification. Image of victim is shown below. This is suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Either A or B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heat ruptures can occur in both antemortem and postmortem burns , making it difficult to distinguish between the two based solely on skin tears or ruptures. Further examination is needed to determine if other signs of antemortem injury, such as inflammation or vital reactions, are present.
  • ➤ Heat ruptures
  • ➤ antemortem
  • ➤ postmortem burns

questions.text: Time since death can be known by all of the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The estimation of time since death relies on postmortem processes that occur in a sequential manner . Rigor mortis follows a predictable pattern and can be used for this purpose, while cadaveric spasm and heat stiffening do not change with time and cannot be used to determine time since death.
  • ➤ sequential manner

questions.text: A 40-year-old university professor who has been charged with the serious assault of a colleague. Professor has been battling untreated schizophrenia, characterized by profound auditory hallucinations and delusions. On the day in question, he was under the delusion that his colleague was a covert agent sent to harm him, leading to the assault. The defence argues that the professor's mental state at the time of the incident rendered him incapable of understanding his actions' nature or distinguishing right from wrong. Given these circumstances and applying the Legal Test of Insanity, how should the professor's criminal responsibility be assessed?

options.label: A
options.text: He is criminally responsible because he was conscious of his physical actions during the assault.

options.label: B
options.text: He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

options.label: C
options.text: He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to control his actions due to his underlying schizophrenia.

options.label: D
options.text: He is criminally responsible because his mental illness does not excuse violent behavior.

questions.correct_answer: B. He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) He is not criminally responsible due to his inability to comprehend the true nature of his actions because of his delusional perception.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students must understand that under the Legal Test of Insanity , criminal responsibility is assessed based on whether the individual, at the time of the offense, was capable of understanding the nature of their actions or distinguishing between right and wrong. Mental illness, especially schizophrenia with delusions, can render an individual incapable of such understanding.
  • ➤ Legal Test of Insanity

questions.text: Pugilistic attitude is due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Intense heat when body temperature is > 65° C

questions.correct_answer: A. Intense heat when body temperature is > 65° C
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pugilistic attitude is caused by intense heat that leads to protein coagulation in the muscles, resulting in the body adopting a characteristic "boxer’s pose." This is unrelated to ATP depletion , which is the mechanism behind rigor mortis.
  • ➤ Pugilistic attitude
  • ➤ intense heat
  • ➤ protein coagulation
  • ➤ ATP depletion

questions.text: In a forensic investigation involving the sudden death of an individual, the autopsy results reveal no signs of trauma, toxicological substances, or pathological conditions. The cause of death remains undetermined despite a thorough gross as well as microscopic examination. What term is commonly used to describe this outcome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Negative autopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative autopsy describes an autopsy where no cause of death can be determined despite thorough investigation. It is important to differentiate this from an obscure autopsy , where microscopic or additional tests may still reveal the cause of death.
  • ➤ negative autopsy
  • ➤ obscure autopsy

questions.text: Characteristic of Joule burn include all except?

options.label: B
options.text: Joule burn is not hyperaemic or only little bit hyperaemic

options.label: C
options.text: Pale raised skin at the margins

options.label: D
options.text: Can be seen at places other than electric contact point

questions.correct_answer: D. Can be seen at places other than electric contact point
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should remember that Joule burns are contact electric burns that occur at the site of electric contact, characterized by round or oval-shaped shallow craters, pale raised margins, and minimal hyperemia. They do not occur away from the electric contact point.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient has been brought in after ingesting an unknown substance at home. The medical officer needs to quickly administer an initial treatment to reduce the absorption of the poison. Which of the following substances, commonly available in medical settings, is a part of this universal antidote and should be administered in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students must remember that activated charcoal is a key component of the universal antidote for poisonings and is commonly used in emergency settings to reduce the absorption of toxins from the gastrointestinal tract.
  • ➤ activated charcoal

questions.text: A forensic investigator is examining a series of bruises on a victim's body. To determine whether these bruises are artificial or true bruises, which of the following characteristics would be most useful to assess?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Color changes over time

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To distinguish between true bruises and artificial bruises , forensic investigators should assess the color changes over time. True bruises show a predictable sequence of color changes as the bruise heals, which does not occur in artificial bruising.
  • ➤ true bruises
  • ➤ artificial bruises
  • ➤ color changes

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who was working in the fields all day, collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. His skin was dry and hot, face was flushed, pulse was fast and thready. Which of the following symptoms are least likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sweating

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that absence of sweating is a key differentiating factor in heat stroke, where the skin is dry and hot. Heat stroke is a severe heat-related condition with body temperature often above 104°F, accompanied by hypotension, fast pulse, and collapse.
  • ➤ absence of sweating

questions.text: A 6-year-old child comes to casualty with history of unknown poisoning by some seed/drug. On examination patient has dilated pupils, dry mouth, delirium and decreased secretions with hallucination. What poisoning should the doctor suspect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dhatura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize the symptoms of anticholinergic poisoning , including dilated pupils, dry mouth, and delirium. Dhatura poisoning is a classic example of anticholinergic toxicity and should be suspected in such cases.
  • ➤ anticholinergic poisoning
  • ➤ Dhatura poisoning

questions.text: A man who was involved in a bomb blast at a railway station was brought to the hospital with rupture of tympanic membrane. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for these injuries?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) High pressure wave

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that primary blast injuries , like tympanic membrane rupture, occur due to the high pressure wave generated by an explosion. This wave primarily affects air-filled organs and is distinct from injuries caused by flying debris (secondary blast injury) or blast winds (tertiary blast injury).
  • ➤ primary blast injuries
  • ➤ high pressure wave

questions.text: Identify the type of wound from the image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Defense wounds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Defense wounds are found on the hands and forearms and are sustained when an individual tries to protect themselves from an attack. They can appear on both the anterior and posterior surfaces and differ from hesitation cuts, which are typically self-inflicted.
  • ➤ Defense wounds

questions.text: A concerned mother takes her daughter of 14 years age who was complaining of pain in the private parts to a gynecologist. On eliciting history, the girl admits she had consensual sexual intercourse with a neighbor. She is 21 weeks pregnant. Which one is true? Take a vaginal Swab MTP cannot be done unless serious congenital anomaly is found Consent of medical board required for MTP No need to inform the police if the victim and mother don’t wish to file a police complaint
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None are true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that in cases involving a minor (under 18), consent for sexual intercourse is irrelevant, and any pregnancy resulting from such an event qualifies as rape under the law. MTP is allowed up to 24 weeks for rape victims, with the consent of two doctors, and healthcare professionals are legally required to report such cases to the police under the POCSO Act.

questions.text: Fish tailing is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Stab wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fishtailing is seen in stab wounds caused by a single-edged weapon , resulting in a wedge-shaped appearance due to the asymmetry of the blade. It helps forensic investigators identify the type of weapon used.
  • ➤ Fishtailing
  • ➤ stab wounds
  • ➤ single-edged weapon

questions.text: A 20-year-old unmarried girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below. Labia majora - separated Labia minora- flabby Old ruptured hymen Deep, roomy, dilated and capacious with less rugosed wall What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Not a virgin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that the physical examination findings related to the condition of the hymen and vaginal structures can suggest prior sexual activity but should be interpreted carefully. The term "virginity" in a clinical context is complex and should not be the sole focus in sensitive cases such as rape investigations, where the emphasis should be on current findings rather than past sexual history.

questions.text: Identify the active principle of the plant shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyoscine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize Datura and understand that its active principles include atropine , hyoscyamine , and hyoscine , all of which have strong anticholinergic effects. These alkaloids are responsible for the toxic effects associated with Datura poisoning.
  • ➤ Datura
  • ➤ atropine
  • ➤ hyoscyamine
  • ➤ hyoscine

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Marshall’s triad in relation to explosive injuries?

options.label: A
options.text: Marshall's triad consists of burns, fractures, and internal bleeding.

options.label: B
options.text: Marshall's triad includes fractures, dislocations, and bone bruises.

options.label: C
options.text: Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.

options.label: D
options.text: Marshall's triad consists of head trauma, chest trauma, and abdominal trauma.

questions.correct_answer: C. Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Marshall's triad refers to bruises, abrasions, and puncture lacerations.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marshall’s triad in secondary blast injuries involves multiple small abrasions, contusions, and lacerations , which result from flying debris after an explosion. This is distinct from primary or tertiary blast injuries.
  • ➤ Marshall’s triad
  • ➤ multiple small abrasions, contusions, and lacerations

questions.text: A 25-year-old man was arrested for sitting naked on a park bench. On police interrogation, he was found to be delirious. Which sexual offence can he be held responsible for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that mental states like delirium can negate criminal intent, making it impossible to hold individuals responsible for certain actions that would otherwise constitute offenses, such as exhibitionism. The presence of a medical condition impacting behavior must be carefully assessed before assigning legal responsibility for actions.
  • ➤ delirium

questions.text: In gunshot injury to skull with entry wound at right temporal region surrounded by abrasion collar & tattooing and an exit wound at left temporal region along with metal fragments of bullet inside the bullet track. What can be used to determine the range of firing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In gunshot injuries involving the skull, the hair should be examined for signs of singeing or blackening from gunpowder residue. This helps in estimating the range of firing , especially when the injury occurs in areas where clothing is not present.
  • ➤ hair
  • ➤ singeing or blackening
  • ➤ range of firing

questions.text: Police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to doctor for medical examination. Mother of the child gives the history that his uncle has been threatening and sexual assaulting him for past 2 years, which she came to know now and complained the police. After doing the complete examination, doctor examines the anus, which shows features as in the picture below. This is suggestive of?
questions.explanation: Ans. D) None of the above

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl, is brought by a lady police sub-inspector, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred few months back. Now the girl is 25 weeks pregnant. Which statement is incorrect as the next course of action?

options.label: C
options.text: Consent of a legal guardian is not mandatory

options.label: D
options.text: MTP cannot be performed unless there are serious congenital abnormalities

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Preserve clothing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that forensic evidence on the body is often lost after a period of time, but clothing may still retain some evidence. However, in this case, the time lapse makes clothing preservation less relevant. They should also remember that the MTP Act allows termination of pregnancy beyond 24 weeks in cases of sexual assault, under certain conditions.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis.

options.label: B
options.text: Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens.

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

questions.correct_answer: D. Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize basophilic stippling as a key feature of lead poisoning , resulting from the disruption of heme synthesis and the accumulation of ribosomal material in red blood cells. This is important in diagnosing children exposed to lead, which can lead to significant anemia and other systemic effects.
  • ➤ basophilic stippling
  • ➤ lead poisoning
  • ➤ ribosomal material

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl, is brought by a lady police sub-inspector to the doctor, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred in the morning same day. Which statement is incorrect as the next course of action by the doctor?

options.label: C
options.text: Consent of a legal guardian is not mandatory to give the medical treatment for injuries to the victim.

options.label: D
options.text: Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage

questions.correct_answer: D. Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Consent of victim is sufficient, and that of legal guardian is not required for MTP if the girl is found to be pregnant at a later stage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The student must remember that for minors under 18 years, the consent of a legal guardian is mandatory for significant medical procedures like MTP. However, for basic medical care, children above the age of 12 can provide consent for treatment of injuries.

questions.text: A mother delivers twins on same day, but with significantly different development and very different features. On DNA testing, only one of the twins matches the husband. What could be the cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Superfetation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superfetation is a rare phenomenon where a second pregnancy occurs during an existing one, resulting in twins of different developmental stages and potentially different fathers.

questions.text: A 48-year-old forensic examiner is presented with a set of preserved clothing articles from a case that is 4 months old. Suspicion arises regarding the presence of aged seminal stains on the fabric. To establish the presence of semen, especially considering the potential degradation of the sample over time, which of the following biochemical tests should the examiner prioritize to yield reliable results?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Creatine phosphokinase test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students must remember that confirmatory tests like the Creatine phosphokinase test should be prioritized in cases of aged or degraded seminal stains due to their specificity, whereas presumptive tests are more sensitive but less specific, and their reliability decreases with time.
  • ➤ confirmatory tests
  • ➤ Creatine phosphokinase test
  • ➤ presumptive tests

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is recommended for acute Lead poisoning with signs of encephalopathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dimercaprol + Calcium EDTA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that in acute lead poisoning with encephalopathy , the combination of Dimercaprol (BAL) and Calcium EDTA is the most effective treatment. Dimercaprol removes lead from the brain, while Calcium EDTA clears it from the blood and other tissues.
  • ➤ acute lead poisoning with encephalopathy
  • ➤ Dimercaprol (BAL)
  • ➤ Calcium EDTA
  • ➤ Dimercaprol
  • ➤ Calcium EDTA

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to ED in a coma with CPR in progress. A friend found him in the schoolyard. His friend confesses that the patient has been depressed over the past several days. His initial labs reveal hypocalcemia and a severe metabolic acidosis. The urine shows calcium oxalate crystals. What was the toxic ingestion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethylene Glycol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, along with hypocalcemia and severe metabolic acidosis , is highly indicative of ethylene glycol poisoning . This condition requires immediate medical intervention due to its life-threatening effects.
  • ➤ calcium oxalate crystals
  • ➤ hypocalcemia
  • ➤ severe metabolic acidosis
  • ➤ ethylene glycol poisoning

questions.text: An approximately twenty-something year old female presents to the emergency department after she collapsed outside a bar. Physical Examination: T: 97.5°F HR: 60 bpm RR: 5 breaths per minute BP: 75/57 mm Hg Pupils are miotic but equal. Neurologic: GCS = 6 (E1V1M4). Best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Naloxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected opioid overdose, characterized by respiratory depression, miotic pupils, and decreased consciousness, Naloxone is the first-line treatment. It is an opioid antagonist that works rapidly to reverse opioid effects, particularly life-threatening respiratory depression.
  • ➤ Naloxone

questions.text: A substance abuser was found on the roadside with low respiratory rate and with pinpoint pupils. Which of the following should be suspected in this drug abuser?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Morphine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark signs of opioid poisoning, including respiratory depression, miosis, and CNS depression. The treatment of choice in an emergency setting for opioid overdose is Naloxone, which rapidly reverses these life-threatening symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with agitation, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. He appears restless and paranoid, and he is sweating profusely. His blood pressure is elevated. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Cocaine poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize the hallmark signs of acute cocaine poisoning , which include agitation , dilated pupils , tachycardia , and elevated blood pressure , due to its powerful stimulant effects on the central nervous system and cardiovascular system.
  • ➤ acute cocaine poisoning
  • ➤ agitation
  • ➤ dilated pupils
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ elevated blood pressure

questions.text: Activated charcoal is ineffective in poisoning of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ethyl alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should remember that activated charcoal is ineffective for substances such as ethyl alcohol, metals, hydrocarbons, and corrosives. For poisoning with these substances, other treatment methods are required.

questions.text: A Casualty medical officer is called to assess a patient who has ingested a toxic substance. During the assessment, the medical officer observes that the patient's urine has turned green. This unusual symptom raises concerns about the specific toxic substance involved. Which toxic substance is most likely responsible for the green-colored urine seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that green-colored urine is a distinguishing feature of phenol (carbolic acid) poisoning , and they should be aware of other associated symptoms to confirm the diagnosis in such cases.
  • ➤ green-colored urine
  • ➤ phenol (carbolic acid) poisoning

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of poisoning. He is conscious but in distress, and reports ingesting a substance about an hour ago. The medical officer notes a distinct smell from the patient's breath. Considering the nature of the substance ingested and the time since ingestion, the medical officer must decide on the appropriate decontamination procedure. For which of the following poisons, consistent with the patient's presentation, is gastric lavage particularly indicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that gastric lavage is contraindicated in most corrosive poisonings except in specific cases like carbolic acid poisoning, where it can be performed cautiously due to the formation of a hard, leathery coating in the stomach.
  • ➤ gastric lavage
  • ➤ carbolic acid

questions.text: A person was brought to emergency with history of snake bite 8 hours ago. The patient had low respiratory rate and bradycardia with drooping of eyelids noted. 10 vials of antivenom were administered. What is the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Give atropine + neostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that atropine and neostigmine are used as adjunctive therapy in neurotoxic snake bites, particularly in cases with neuromuscular weakness and respiratory depression, following the administration of antivenom.
  • ➤ atropine and neostigmine

questions.text: After visiting a village, a 5-year-old boy began crying intensely during the return trip. Within three hours, he was brought to the emergency department. He displayed symptoms such as altered consciousness, cold and sweaty extremities, heightened salivation, and excessive sweating. Physical examination revealed paleness and priapism, along with vital signs as follows: blood pressure of 140/78 mmHg, heart rate of 152 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that prazosin is the treatment of choice for scorpion envenomation , as it counteracts the excessive sympathetic stimulation caused by the venom. The classic presentation includes tachycardia , hypertension , excessive salivation , and priapism .
  • ➤ prazosin
  • ➤ scorpion envenomation
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ hypertension
  • ➤ excessive salivation
  • ➤ priapism

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents to the emergency department with severe pain, restlessness, hypertension, tachycardia, and sweating after being stung by a scorpion. The sting site is red and swollen, with no signs of necrosis. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Apply a tourniquet proximal to the sting site

options.label: D
options.text: Cleanse the wound and apply ice packs

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Administer prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that prazosin is the treatment of choice in scorpion envenomation presenting with systemic symptoms like hypertension , tachycardia , and excessive sweating , as it helps to alleviate the effects of sympathetic overactivity caused by the venom.
  • ➤ prazosin
  • ➤ scorpion envenomation
  • ➤ hypertension
  • ➤ tachycardia
  • ➤ excessive sweating

questions.text: A middle aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails and rain drop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above mentioned symptoms is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arsenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that chronic arsenic poisoning is associated with skin changes like hyperkeratosis , Mees' lines , and raindrop pigmentation , along with neurological symptoms such as paraesthesia . This is especially relevant in regions known for arsenic contamination, such as West Bengal .
  • ➤ chronic arsenic poisoning
  • ➤ hyperkeratosis
  • ➤ Mees' lines
  • ➤ raindrop pigmentation
  • ➤ paraesthesia
  • ➤ West Bengal

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that strychnine poisoning presents with opisthotonus , conscious seizures , and intense muscle spasms, which are distinct features that help in diagnosing this toxic exposure.
  • ➤ strychnine poisoning
  • ➤ opisthotonus
  • ➤ conscious seizures

questions.text: Identify the plant shown in the image below and the condition it is responsible for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that ergot poisoning arises from consuming rye or other grains infected by the fungus Claviceps purpurea , and it can result in severe vasoconstrictive and neurologic symptoms.
  • ➤ ergot poisoning
  • ➤ rye
  • ➤ Claviceps purpurea

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should be able to recognize the marking nut ( Semecarpus anacardium ) and understand that its active toxic principle is bhilawanol , which can cause toxic reactions upon exposure.
  • ➤ marking nut
  • ➤ Semecarpus anacardium
  • ➤ bhilawanol

questions.text: A 28-year-old male arrives in the emergency department after being exposed to an unidentified toxic substance given to him by a friend. His symptoms include dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation. During the examination, his pulse rate is recorded at 140 beats per minute, and his pupils are observed to be dilated. Which substance is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Belladona

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize that Belladonna poisoning produces anticholinergic symptoms such as dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, urinary retention, and constipation. This presentation helps differentiate it from other toxic substances like opioids or organophosphates.
  • ➤ Belladonna poisoning
  • ➤ anticholinergic symptoms
